content: Who can tell me what the state is of stdsimd, core_arch, and std_detect on crates.io? The README in the stdarch repo says that repo contains two of those, but it's been 2Â½ years since anything was published.
cc @Amanieu @Alex Crichton maybe?

I don't think I published those originally, but my guess is that they were intended to reflect the work-in-progress state of development for stdarch for nightly users. Nowadays I think it's probably best to have a readme that says "don't use these, use std::arch" and go that route

yeah, the readme on crates.io already says

core::arch is available as part of libcore and it is re-exported by libstd. Prefer using it via core::arch or std::arch than via this crate.

so the only thing left is probably just updating the readme in the repository to not point to those crates.
want me to invite you to the crates.io versions?

sure, might be useful at some point if we rename/add teams or something. the libs team is already owner, but apparently being owner through a team doesn't give the possibility of adding new teams/owners.

Essentially, stdarch, used to be called stdsimd and was an external (nightly-only) crate. Since it is now part of the standard library, the crates.io versions are basically unmaintained and should not be used.
thanks! sounds like #1197 is the right thing then.
